introduction.p: We now define the derivative explicitly, based on the limiting slope ideas of the previous section. Then we see how to compute some simple derivatives.

Let us now generalise what we did in the last section so as to find the slope of the curve y=f(x) at (x_0,y_0) for any smooth enough
The idea of smooth enough can be made quite precise. Indeed the word smooth has a very precise meaning in mathematics, which we won't cover here. For now think of smooth as meaning roughly just smooth.
function f(x).

As before, let (x_0,y_0) be any point on the curve y=f(x). So we must have y_0=f(x_0). Now let (x_1,y_1) be any other point on the same curve. So y_1=f(x_1) and x_1\ne x_0. Think of (x_1,y_1) as being pretty close to (x_0,y_0) so that the difference
\De x=x_1-x_0
in xcoordinates is pretty small. In terms of this \De x we have
x_1=x_0+\De x\qquad\text{and}\qquad y_1=f\big(x_0+\De x\big)
We can construct a secant line through (x_0,y_0) and (x_1,y_1) just as we did for the parabola above. It has slope
\frac{y_1-y_0}{x_1-x_0}=\frac{f\big(x_0+\De x\big)-f(x_0)}{\De x}
If f(x) is reasonably smooth
Again the term reasonably smooth can be made more precise. , then as x_1 approaches x_0, i.e. as \De x approaches 0, we would expect the secant through (x_0,y_0) and (x_1,y_1) to approach the tangent line to the curve y=f(x) at (x_0,y_0), just as happened in Figure . And more importantly, the slope of the secant through (x_0,y_0) and (x_1,y_1) should approach the slope of the tangent line to the curve y=f(x) at (x_0,y_0).

Thus we would expect Indeed, we don't have to expect it is! the slope of the tangent line to the curve y=f(x) at (x_0,y_0) to be
\lim_{\De x\rightarrow 0}\frac{f\big(x_0+\De x\big)-f(x_0)}{\De x}
When we talk of the slope of the curve at a point, what we really mean is the slope of the tangent line to the curve at that point. So the slope of the curve y=f(x) at (x_0,y_0) is also the limit
This is of course under the assumption that the limit exists we will talk more about that below.
expressed in the above equation. The derivative of f(x) at x=x_0 is also defined to be this limit. Which leads
We will rename x_0 to a and \De x to h.
us to the most important definition in this text:

statement.p:
Let a\in\bbbr and let f(x) be defined on an open interval
Recall, from Definition, that the open interval (c,d) is just the set of all real numbers obeying c \lt x \lt d.
that contains a.
The derivative of f(x) at x=a is denoted f'(a) and is defined by
f'(a)=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{f\big(a+h\big)-f(a)}{h}
if the limit exists.
When the above limit exists, the function f(x) is said to be differentiable at x=a. When the limit does not exist, the function f(x) is said to be not differentiable at x=a.
We can equivalently define the derivative f'(a) by the limit
f'(a)=\lim_{x\rightarrow a}\frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a}.
To see that these two definitions are the same, we set x=a+h and then the limit as h goes to 0 is equivalent to the limit as x goes to a.

introduction.p: Lets now compute the derivatives of some very simple functions. This is our first step towards building up a toolbox for computing derivatives of complicated functions this process will very much parallel what we did in Chapter with limits. The two simplest functions we know are f(x)=c and g(x)=x.

example.title: Derivative of f(x)=c
example.p: Let a, c \in \bbbr be a constants. Compute the derivative of the constant function f(x) = c at x=a.

introduction.p: That was easy! What about the next most complicated function arguably it's this one:

example.title: Derivative of g(x)=x
example.p: Let a\in \bbbr and compute the derivative of g(x) = x at x=a.

introduction.p: That was a little harder than the first example, but still quite straight forward start with the definition and apply what we know about limits.
Thanks to these two examples, we have our first theorem about derivatives:

statement.p:
Let a,c \in \mathbb{R} and let f(x) = c be the constant function and g(x) = x. Then
f'(a) &= 0
and g'(a) &= 1.

introduction.p: To ratchet up the difficulty a little bit more, let us redo the example we have already done a few times f(x)=x^2. To make it a little more interesting let's change the names of the function and the variable so that it is not exactly the same as Examples and.

example.title: Derivative of h(t)=t^2
example.p:
Compute the derivative of
h(t) &= t^2 & \text{ at } t = a

ul.li: This function isn't quite like the ones we saw earlier it's a function of t rather than x. Recall that a function is a rule which assigns to each input value an output value. So far, we have usually called the input value x. But this x is just a dummy variable representing a generic input value. There is nothing wrong with calling a generic input value t instead. Indeed, from time to time you will see functions that are not written as formulas involving x, but instead are written as formulas in t (for example representing time see Section), or z (for example representing height), or other symbols.

But there is a problem h plays two roles here it is both the function name and the small quantity that is going to zero in our limit. It is extremely dangerous to have a symbol represent two different things in a single computation. We need to change one of them. So let's rename the small quantity that is going to zero in our limit from h to \De t:
h'(a) &= \lim_{\De t \to 0} \frac{h(a+\De t)-h(a)}{\De t}
You should go back check that this is what we got in Example just some names have been changed.

subsection.title: An important point (and some notation)
subsection.p:
Notice here that the answer we get depends on our choice of a if we want to know the derivative at a=3 we can just substitute a=3 into our answer 2a to get the slope is 6. If we want to know at a=1 (like at the end of Section) we substitute a=1 and get the slope is 2. The important thing here is that we can move from the derivative being computed at a specific point to the derivative being a function itself input any value of a and it returns the slope of the tangent line to the curve at the point x=a, y=h(a). The variable a is a dummy variable. We can rename a to anything we want, like x, for example. So we can replace every a in
h'(a)&=2a &\text{ by $x$, giving} && h'(x) &=2x
where all we have done is replaced the symbol a by the symbol x.

statement.p:
Let f(x) be a function.
The derivative of f(x) with respect to x is
f'(x)=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{f\big(x+h\big)-f(x)}{h}
provided the limit exists.
If the derivative f'(x) exists for all x \in (a,b) we say that f is differentiable on (a,b).
Note that we will sometimes be a little sloppy with our discussions and simply write f is differentiable to mean f is differentiable on an interval we are interested in or f is differentiable everywhere.

subsection.p: Notice that we are no longer thinking of tangent lines, rather this is an operation we can do on a function. For example:

example.title: The derivative of f(x)=\tfrac{1}{x}

subsection.p:
So we now have two slightly different ideas of derivatives:
The derivative f'(a) at a specific point x=a, being the slope of the tangent line to the curve at x=a, and
The derivative as a function, f'(x) as defined in Definition.
Of course, if we have f'(x) then we can always recover the derivative at a specific point by substituting x=a.

As we noted at the beginning of the chapter, the derivative was discovered independently by Newton and Leibniz in the late 17^{\rm th} century. Because their discoveries were independent, Newton and Leibniz did not have exactly the same notation. Stemming from this, and from the many different contexts in which derivatives are used, there are quite a few alternate notations for the derivative:

statement.p:
The following notations are all used for the derivative of f(x) with respect to x
f'(x) \qquad \diff{f}{x} \qquad \diff{}{x}f(x) \qquad \dot{f}(x) \qquad Df(x) \qquad D_x f(x),
while the following notations are all used for the derivative of f(x) at x=a
f'(a) \qquad \diff{f}{x}(a) \qquad \diff{}{x}f(x)\,\bigg|_{x=a} \qquad \dot{f}(a) \qquad Df(a) \qquad D_x f(a).

Some things to note about these notations:
We will generally use the first three, but you should recognise them all. The notation f'(a) is due to Lagrange, while the notation \diff{f}{x}(a) is due to Leibniz. They are both very useful. Neither can be considered better.
Leibniz notation writes the derivative as a fraction however it is definitely not a fraction and should not be thought of in that way. It is just shorthand, which is read as the derivative of f with respect to x.
You read f'(x) as fprime of x, and \diff{f}{x} as deefdeex, and \diff{ }{x}f(x) as dee-by-deex of f.
Similarly you read \diff{f}{x}(a) as deefdeex at a, and \diff{ }{x}f(x)|_{x=a} as dee-by-dee-x of f of x at x equals a.
The notation \dot f is due to Newton. In physics, it is common to use \dot f(t) to denote the derivative of f with respect to time.

subsection.title: Back to computing some derivatives
subsection.p: At this point we could try to start working out how derivatives interact with arithmetic and make an Arithmetic of derivatives theorem just like the one we saw for limits (Theorem ). We will get there shortly, but before that it is important that we become more comfortable with computing derivatives using limits and then understanding what the derivative actually means. So more examples.

example.p: Compute the derivative, f'(a), of the function f(x)=\sqrt{x} at the point x=a for any a \gt 0.

ul.li: As x tends to a, the numerator and denominator both tend to zero. But \tfrac{0}{0} is not defined. So to get a well defined limit we need to exhibit a cancellation between the numerator and denominator just as we saw in Examples and. Now there are two equivalent ways to proceed from here, both based on a similar trick.

li.p: We should think about the domain of f' here that is, for which values of a is f'(a) defined? The original function f(x) was defined for all x \geq 0, however the derivative f'(a)=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{a}} is undefined at a = 0.

If we draw a careful picture of \sqrt{x} around x=0 we can see why this has to be the case. The figure below shows three different tangent lines to the graph of y=f(x)=\sqrt{x}. As the point of tangency moves closer and closer to the origin, the tangent line gets steeper and steeper. The slope of the tangent line at \big(a,\sqrt{a}\big) blows up as a\to 0.

subsection.title: Where is the derivative undefined?
subsection.p:
According to Definition , the derivative f'(a) exists precisely when the limit \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a} \dfrac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a} exists. That limit is also the slope of the tangent line to the curve y=f(x) at x=a. That limit does not exist when the curve y=f(x) does not have a tangent line at x=a or when the curve does have a tangent line, but the tangent line has infinite slope. We have already seen some examples of this.
In Example , we considered the function f(x)=\frac{1}{x}. This function blows up (i.e. becomes infinite) at x=0. It does not have a tangent line at x=0 and its derivative does not exist at x=0.
In Example , we considered the function f(x)=|x|. This function does not have a tangent line at x=0, because there is a sharp corner in the graph of y=|x| at x=0. (Look at the graph in Example 2.2.10.) So the derivative of f(x)=|x| does not exist at x=0.
Here are a few more examples.

example.title: Derivative at a discontinuity

example.p: Visually, it looks like the function f(x) = x^{1/3}, sketched below, (this might be a good point to recall that cube roots of negative numbers are negative for example, since (-1)^3=-1, the cube root of -1 is -1),
We have already considered the derivative of the function \sqrt{x} in Example . We'll now look at the function f(x) = \sqrt{|x|}. Recall, from Example , the definition of |x|.

When x \gt 0, we have |x|=x and f(x) is identical to \sqrt{x}. When x \lt 0, we have |x|=-x and f(x)=\sqrt{-x}. So to graph y=\sqrt{|x|} when x \lt 0, you just have to graph y=\sqrt{x} for x \gt 0 and then send x\rightarrow -x i.e. reflect the graph in the yaxis. Here is the graph.

statement.p: If the function f(x) is differentiable at x=a, then f(x) is also continuous at x=a.

proof.p:
The function f(x) is continuous at x=a if and only if the limit of
f(a+h) - f(a) = \frac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h}\ h
as h\rightarrow 0 exists and is zero. But if f(x) is differentiable at x=a, then, as h\rightarrow 0, the first factor, \frac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h} converges to f'(a) and the second factor, h, converges to zero. So the product provision of our arithmetic of limits Theorem implies that the product \frac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h}\ h converges to f'(a)\cdot 0=0 too.

subsection.p:
Notice that while this theorem is useful as stated, it is (arguably) more often applied in its contrapositive
If you have forgotten what the contrapositive is, then quickly reread Footnote in Section.
form:

statement.p: If f(x) is not continuous at x=a then it is not differentiable at x=a.

subsection.p: As the above examples illustrate, this statement does not tell us what happens if f is continuous at x=a we have to think!
